An ugly divorce, a brutal murder, a sniper-style shooting of a judge standing near a window.
This could come from a novel, but it's a real story out of Reno, Nevada.
On a June morning a year ago, legal affairs reporter Martha Bellisle of the Reno Gazette-Journal heard a call over the police scanner that a sniper had just shot a judge in downtown Reno.
His office in the courthouse was on the third floor and it faced the Truckee River.
And two blocks away, there was a parking structure, and apparently someone had driven up onto the fifth floor and shot from that floor through his window and hit him with some shrapnel in his chest.
So the judge survived, but the story gets stranger.
Let's back up a couple of hours earlier and go to the Reno townhouse of a wealthy pawnshop owner named Darren Mack.
He was in the middle of a bitter divorce from his wife, Charla; she had just dropped off their child at the house.
Darren had another friend waiting to take the girl to her grandmother's.
Darren wanted to talk with Charla.
They went into the garage for privacy.
Pretty soon, there was some scuffling and the dog barking.
And Darren came walking up the stairs with a funny look on his face and his hand wrapped in a towel.
And the dog came upstairs with blood on him.
So the friend was a little bit concerned.
So he took the daughter out the front door and took off.
And then the friend called the police.
And when they got to the townhouse, they found Charla's body in the garage, on the floor; she'd been stabbed to death and Darren was gone.
